div1.p: Kellogg thanks Hench for providing so much information for Cornwell's painting. He will discuss changes in the painting with Cornwell.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 7, 1941
div1.p:
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
February 7th, 1941 Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:

Mr. Douglas J. Withington of John Wyeth & Brother, Philadelphia
gave me your recent letter concerning the new painting on “The
Conquest of Yellow Fever”. I also have your article on Lazear
which I found most interesting.

When Mr. Cornwell visited Cuba last October I accompanied him,
at which time we got what we thought was adequate background on
Finlay, as well as the work that the U.S. Army Commission had
done.

We are to be in Washington, D.C. Monday and Tuesday of this week
with Mr. Cornwell, who has now completed two preliminary sketches
in oil.

Since reading your letter and your article we feel it is quite
essential to show you these sketches before he starts doing the
work on canvas. Would it be possible for Mr. Withington and
myself to see you a week from this coming Monday, or Tuesday;
that is February 17th or 18th? We could arrange this easily
as we have to go to Chicago about that time. If some other date
a little later would be more convenient, I believe that it could
be arranged. We will, of course, bring Mr. Cornwell's sketches
with us.

If you can wire me at the above address, collect, it will facilitate
making the arrangements for this trip.
With our many thanks for your cooperation, I am

Very truly yours,
George Kellogg
George A. Kellogg:ef
CC - Mr. D. J. Withington

At the time I wrote the copy I had never heard of Finlay, as far as
I can recall, so when we got down to paragraph 4, in preparing the
telegram from New York, the writer says, - “Its contents about Dr.
Finlay were not the same as that of the above-mentioned pamphlet”. In
other words, they already began to suspect us of duplicity. We were
perfectly innocent in the matter, however, for two years ago I thought
of no one but Walter Reed and his Commission, and two weeks before we
went to Cuba I had been sold the bill of goods on the Finlay idea, and
really began to place Walter Reed pretty far down the scale in im-
portance, feeling that Reed and his doctors had stolen all the glory
from Finlay. It now becomes the privilege and duty of John Wyeth &
Brother to attempt to do in a picture painted by Cornwell what you are
doing in your writings; in other words, to give a fair and well-balanced
credit to all. The more I read about Moran and Kissenger, the more I
feel that they should be in the picture. I will talk to Cornwell about
this tonight.

To get down to paragraph 5 in the translation, in the light of our
recent conversation, I think this is very funny. I was present at only
part of that interview and did not realize that Cornwell was committing
himself to the extent of assuring them that Dr. Finlay would be the
central figure in the picture. As you have said, it certainly turned
out that way in the sketches which you have seen.

On page 3 of the translation it is perfectly obvious that, as someone
has said, the Cubans are making a God of Finlay. They are prejudiced
in his favor. One reason, I suppose, is that they really don't under-
stand anything about the technical requirements of proving such a
theory as Finlay did have.had.

I won't take any more of your time for the present, but it seems to me
that there will be a little hell raised in Cuba when we show the finished
picture, butperhaps we'd better show them nothing but the preliminary sketches.
We will discuss this later.

With kindest regards to Mrs. Hench and our thanks for your splendid co-
operation and hospitality, I am

Very truly yours,
George A. Kellogg
George A. Kellogg
RO
Encl.
